title: Will Hassan Rouhani cease to be president of Iran before 1 October 2019?

There are several ways this question could come through:  a) The president is killed - only happened once in 40 years. b) The president has stepped down or is impeached, or otherwise pushed out by government change. In the past 40 years, this has only happened once in Iran.  c) The president dies of natural causes This is the easiest to check; I'm using US stats because the president presumably has good healthcare, being fairly wealthy. Hassan Rouhani is 70 years old, which puts his death odds over the next three months at about .5% (https://www.ssa.gov/oact/STATS/table4c6.html#fn1) In total this puts the odds of the question coming through at around 2%; I'm trying to find some other baseline stat for similar countries in the region though it's tricky to find appropriate comparisons. Specifically to recent news stories, on one hand further confrontations with the US may escalate tensions in the region and further hurt the economy, angering people, but on the other hand friendly countries still buy Iranian oil and strengthen the President.
Doubling the odds to 2. The increase in sanctions effectiveness could just cause someone to panic.

I don't really see any reason he would cease to be president. There were some calls for resignation/impeachment by some hardliners, but Rouhani seems to have successfully convinced Iranians that the US is their biggest threat and the cause of all their economic woes.  https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2019/feb/24/hassan-rouhani-irans-president-faces-impeachment-b/?utm_source=GOOGLE&utm_medium=cpc&utm_id=chacka&utm_campaign=TWT+-+DSA&gclid=CjwKCAjw0ZfoBRB4EiwASUMdYZy7vLm9O3jPww-eQLoWSZJuVUKRSJUROGDYbNZboJ2w038eoiIN1xoCETIQAvD_BwE https://www.cnbc.com/2019/02/24/irans-president-faces-calls-to-resign-over-economic-crisis.html
https://www.timesofisrael.com/rouhani-urges-iranians-to-put-all-your-curses-on-zionists-us/

Supreme Leader Khamenei distances himself from the JCPOA. Khamenei may be increasingly inclined to abandon the JCPOA and could decide to do so after July 7, which marks the end of Iran’s 60-day deadline to Europe to provide Iran economic guarantees [1]
Khamenei noted that he frequently expressed his lack of confidence to President Hassan Rouhani and Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif [1] What are the chances Europe will respond positively to Iran's deadline, in the middle of top roles' renovation? With reduced crude exports [2] and into recession [3], what good would it make for Iran to terminate JCPOA? Khamenei is probably sending messages, and terminating Rouhani could be just another one. Question as with everything is about time.  [1] https://www.criticalthreats.org/briefs/iran-file/khamenei-prepares-for-the-jcpoas-potential-collapse

Hassan Rouhani may cease to be president because in the past year Iran has undergone an economic crisis that has triggered massive domestic demonstrations. Also, these demonstrations have shifted their focus from economic aggression to overthrow the president.
Claudia has an excellent rational for why No is the right answer in the short term.

American sanctions have greatly affected Iran's government causing their trade, economy, and investments to shrink by a significant amount. This economic crisis arose during President Hassan Rouhani's second four-year term and has left him especially vulnerable to protestors calling for his removal from office (https://worldin2019.economist.com/iranunderpressure). Rouhani has faced major backlash from hard-line forces, clerics, and the public for his handling of the sanctions placed by America, and he is also blamed for the country's current economic crisis (https://www.cnbc.com/2019/02/24/irans-president-faces-calls-to-resign-over-economic-crisis.html). Although there have been calls to disqualify him as president by nine hard-line lawmakers, Rouhani's presidency is coming to an end in 2021 and his removal would require a vote by two-thirds of the 290 members of their parliament. He will most likely continue to be president after October 1, 2019 because garnering the support needed in parliament to have him disqualified will take a significant amount of time if it is actually feasible.

As the public continues to be challenged by the deteriorating economic state within Iran, many want anyone but Hassan Rouhani as President as long as they give notice to the general population. Currently, there are hardline activists seeking disqualification of Rouhani in his role or hoping that he will resign. However, Iran is a relatively stable country compared to others, and its next election is coming up. The government has a good hold on its position, and Rouhani will most likely stay on as President past 1 October 2019. Sources:
https://worldin2019.economist.com/iranunderpressure
https://www.cnbc.com/2019/02/24/irans-president-faces-calls-to-resign-over-economic-crisis.html
https://www.voanews.com/a/iran-elected-president-appointed-supreme-leader-in-charge/4190031.html
Something big, like an American-led campaign to topple him, would be needed to oust him from power. He's too entrenched, with solid military and political support around hm.

There electoral system is frail and there us tampering from the regime against opposition (As happens with most developing countries).  The regime is too strong and the lack of interest from other democratic countries to leverage any change will not help oust Rouhani before his term is complete

His term has a few years yet to run, so he is likely to remain through 1 Oct 2019. He is 70 years old, so there is a higher risk of death than with a younger leader. There is also a risk of assassination etc. But I consider this small (Iran is relatively stable country).
There are no elections planned and insufficient pressure to make him stand down
Current US aggressive posturing ironically probably helps him on the domestic political front

The regime represented by the clerics want to protect their view point.  As the economy continues to deteriorate for the common population, violence may well erupt.  A scapegoat is needed.   Hassan Rouhani will be replaced one way or another.
Rouhani is too much of a pragmatic, moderate deep thinker to  not survive past October 1.
More than ever his people will be depending on him.
Political situation in Iran has been stable for many years - strong negative for change, some social unrest - very weak chance of change

Base rate: as others have pointed out one president has been impeached, one assassinated since the 1979 revolution [1]. That yields 2/8=25% as base rate for any president to not finish term. Per year, one would expect such an event with 2/40=5% probability. The latter seems much more informative than the former. With about half a year left, this goes down to 2.5%. Adjustments:
- Death: given his age of 70 [2], he'd have a 2.3% chance of dying in the US [3]. I couldn't find any numbers for Iran. Adjusting upward to 2.8% to account for Iran seems sensible. Dividing to account for time until October yields 1.4%. Adding that to the 2.5% base rate we get 3.9%.
- This AP article [3] does make it seem as if there was good reason to expect something to happen: "Nine hard-line lawmakers have put forward a measure to disqualify Rouhani as president. His dismissal would require two-thirds of parliament’s 290 members [...] Iranian law also allows Rouhani to resign, and criminal charges could push him from his post." Neither of these seem particularly likely or concrete. Still, adjusting to 5% seems reasonable. [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_Iran
[2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hassan_Rouhani
[3] https://www.apnews.com/8bdb076cef644b35b384012c05e1984d

Under the leadership of Ayatollah Khamenei all presidents remain in power for 8 years. Practically there is no impeachment in Islamic Republic because the president does not elect in a fully democratic way. The president was selected indirectly by The Leader. only in the case of Khamenei's death, Revolutionary Guard Corps coup or a war with a foreign country can lead to ceasing the presidency of Rouhani. these three events are still unlikely to happen.
Don't miss any opportunity, every drop counts... https://www.jpost.com/Middle-East/Iran-News/Iran-faces-massive-crises-over-flooding-585328

Base Case: Only 2 Iranian presidents have been removed since the Iranian revolution, 1 by impeachment the other by assassination. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_Iran That yields a base rate of 28% chance of removal. However, in recent times no president has been removed.Ali Khamenei, Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, Mohammad Khatami, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad and Hassan Rouhani were each elected president for two terms. That leads me to revise the base rate downwards.In addition Rouhani has been re-elected and this is his final term. The Iranian parliament is majortiy ruled by his party so impeachment is rather unlikely. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Islamic_Consultative_Assembly That leaves only assassination. With only one prior instance and that decades ago also unlikely.

The baseline scenario is that he serves out his term which carries him to 2021. None of the last three presidents have resigned, been impeached or have been assassinated. Rouhani appears to be upping his conservative chops all the time: ( http://www.arabnews.com/node/1472326 ). Given that domestic economic issues are the biggest problem and that there is no easy fix to this other than giving up nuclear weapons that they believe are essential to their existence, I do not see a contender coming forward with a believable plan to oust Rouhani that the nation will rally behind. Leaving 1% chance of lightning strike, lion attack during mountain bike race or the IRGC deciding they can insure oil shipments and do EU business with a new cryptocurrency that requires a geeky new president.

Absolutely not. Iran is an extremely stable country with an economy that is outperforming every single western economy. It is on par with the Chinese economy.
The source quotes voa, cnbc, and other propaganda outlets suggesting that there are protests or riots or any sort of unrest. There is more unrest in the west (france has actual rioting for 4-6 months now) and rising fascist movements (not just trump, but 100% out of the closet kkk, neofascists, etc) that want to carry out genocide, and a large segment of the western population is supporting them.

Who will lead the “death to America” chants and lecture on “the great Satan”? Clerics and revolutionary guard aren’t (complete) morons. Status quo suits everyone best. No need for a political sacrifice just yet. Iran will face its time of disruption at some time in near future, however (based on demography and access to info/influences outside Iran).

Only one president has been impeached and one assassinated since the revolution and it seems the system has settled into a two full term norm. The economic problems can easily be blamed on the US thanks to reimposed economic sanctions and regional hostility. The situaion could change rapidly (mass violence in the streets, death of Khomeini, precipitous fall in oil revenue) but right now Rouhani seems stable.

Unless Rouhani dies, his despotic control will be well defended and absolute by the tight circle around him. This is a country accustomed to hardship, and sanctions are unlikely to sway those who have the power to make change.
Iranian presidents are seldom impeached, and in the last election he won over half the votes.
I don’t see any such move in the timeframe stated. American sanctions are an easy scapegoat for he economic issues facing Iran. Rouhani is likely secure for now.

Iran just struck a hoard of deals with Iraq, and Washington isn’t happy
https://www.cnbc.com/2019/03/20/iran-just-struck-several-deals-with-iraq-and-washington-isnt-happy.html Crude production from Iran and Venezuela has remained resilient in the face of US sanctions, Saudi energy minister Khalid al-Falih said Sunday, so for now, OPEC and its allies "need to stay the course, certainly until June," on their 1.2 million b/d oil cut agreement. "The fact of the matter is that [Iran and Venezuela] have not declined precipitously -- to the point where we see there are still inventory builds," Falih said in Baku, Azerbaijan, a day ahead of a key OPEC/non-OPEC monitoring committee meeting. He noted that Venezuela has redirected some of its crude flows to Asia and away from US Gulf refiners, who are practically banned from importing Venezuelan oil due to US sanctions. "Therefore, the market overall remains supplied with Venezuelan barrels," Falih said. "The overall supply situation remains long and is forecasted to be long for the  Venezuelan production fell to 1.10 million b/d in February, down from 1.16 million b/d in January, according to the latest S&P Global Platts survey of OPEC output, though a recent massive power outage in the country is expected to significantly impact output levels. Iran, meanwhile, held production steady at 2.72 million b/d in February, unchanged month on month, the survey found, as sanctions waivers the US granted to eight countries to continue Iranian oil purchases help buoy output. The waivers expire in May, and US officials have not said whether they plan to extend them.
https://www.spglobal.com/platts/en/market-insights/latest-news/oil/031819-iran-venezuela-sanctions-impacts-not-dire-enough-to-justify-easing-opec-oil-cuts-falih
Social stability is the first thing for Iran

A few points about this: There is only one precedent of impeachment of a president of Iran, and it was back in 1981 right after 1979 revolution. No historical reference can be used from this. The Supreme Leader of Iran, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei is said to be ill ([1] this post should be taken carefully), and some sources point to disputes over succession taking place now. [2][3] The country is struggling economically: "In May 2017, the re-election of President Hasan RUHANI generated widespread public expectations that the economic benefits of the JCPOA [the nuclear agreement] would expand and reach all levels of society. RUHANI will need to implement structural reforms that strengthen the banking sector and improve Iran’s business climate to attract foreign investment and encourage the growth of the private sector. Sanctions that are not related to Iran’s nuclear program remain in effect, and these—plus fears over the possible re-imposition of nuclear-related sanctions—will continue to deter foreign investors from engaging with Iran." [4] The economic situation sparked civil unrest, demonstrations and potential political instability: “Tehran can’t afford to buy off the protesters while the country is in economic free fall,”...“Trump’s Iran policy has made matters worse for Tehran. 'The sanctions are successful in putting pressure on the regime, shaking the regime'” [5] "Daily protests continue in Iran, as the economy sinks. “America is not the enemy, the enemy is right here,” say some in the crowds. " [6] Options:
Scenario one: nothing happens until Khamenei passes on, certainly changes can wait until that moment (why would anyone start any earlier given the situation?). Iran's leaders keep on looking for sanctions to be eased (related or not to the nuclear agreement JCPOA) as desperately needing resources to implement economic measures that relief social pressure. Assuming it takes some time, longer than October 1st: YES 2.5% Cromwell's rule.
Scenario two: same as one, but no uplift of sanctions and unrest increases rapidly, asking for Rouhani's impeachment (long term) or resignation (short term): YES 5%
Scenario three: Khamenei passes on before October 1st (say 40% before August 1st - not sure if it matters but Ramadam this year ends on June 4th) and succession war begins: "Since December 2017, the IRGC [the Revolutionary Guard] and Rohani have tried to mobilise the public against each other in anticipation of a succession battle." [3]. Hardliners and IRGC win, using IRGC economic power and civil society, and Rouhani is removed from position. No idea about how quickly this could be (Khamenei's own appointment was probably already designated by his predecessor, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini) but we can assume it to be quickly after: YES 24%
Scenario four: same as three, but conflict between reformist and clerical government escalates, even possibly to civil war and takes much longer. During this time, Rouhani continues as President. YES: 0%. Total: 31.5% [1] https://www.washingtonpost.com/outlook/2019/01/13/why-us-must-know-truth-about-health-irans-supreme-leader/?utm_term=.24d81c024df2
[2] https://nationalinterest.org/feature/irans-battle-over-khameneis-successor-just-getting-started-43252
[3] https://thearabweekly.com/power-struggle-tehran-ahead-post-khamenei-succession
[4] https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/ir.html
[5] https://thearabweekly.com/iran-set-see-more-unrest-2019-economy-falters
[6] https://www.economist.com/middle-east-and-africa/2019/02/09/four-decades-after-its-revolution-iran-is-still-stuck-in-the-past

4 out of 5 previous presidents reached their maximum tenure of 8 years, so an anchor around 20 % seems reasonable. The short time frame of the question would suggest a downward pressure on the probability, but also short term pressure seems to be high on Rouhani, so I would adjust slightly upwards.

Rouhani could become the Supreme Leader if Khamenei dies.  And, of course, he would cease to be the president if he died.  The mortality rates for men aged 70 and 79 in the US are 0.023351 and 0.053228 respectively.  If Khamenei dies, I give a 50-50 chance of Rouhani succeeding him, given that Khamenei seems to be grooming his son for the position.  Also, because of friction between the two, I'll triple their mortality rates as a very imperfect way of accounting for assassination.   (1-0.023351*3) * (1-0.053228*3/2) = 0.8557
Prorating for 1/2 year: (1-0.8557)/2 = 0.0722
7% chance. https://www.ssa.gov/oact/STATS/table4c6.html
https://en.radiofarda.com/a/iran-rouhani-remarks-reveal-rift-with-khamenei/29701925.html

1) Base rate is 18%, only 2 presidents have not finished their term - 1 assassination / 1 impeachment. [1] (2 unfinished terms / 11 total terms = 0.18)* 2) Of the possible ways Rouhani could leave office before this question closes; assassination, untimely death or medical emergency, revolution, resignation, or impeachment, the first four seem very unlikely and the last one depends on the supreme leader and the guardian council. [2] Since Iran just sent Rouhani to Iraq to complete a major deal, this demonstrates that Rouhani still has the support of Iran's leadership. [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_Iran
[2] http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8051750.stm
* not counting Rouhani's current term
Things would have to get a lot worse fairly quickly for this to happen.  I think.
